awd_titl_txt: Math Classrooms, Student Mindsets and STEM Pathways in High School
awd_abstract_narration:
The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that will generate foundational knowledge in the field. This study will add to foundational knowledge by building theory about broadening participation of underrepresented minority groups (students of color, young women, students from low SES families, students with disabilities, English language learners), and intersections among them, in STEM education. The study will use data from the National Study of Learning Mindsets (NSLM), the largest (to date) national randomized-controlled trial of a psychological intervention conducted with a national probability sample of public high schools and an over-sample of urban district schools, including over 18,000 students from 83 schools. The goal of the NSLM was to gain insights about ways to retain underrepresented students in the STEM pipeline. Through the intervention students were taught the concept of a growth mindset (the idea that the struggles in school are opportunities to learn, and do not mean you lack intelligence), and how to apply this concept in their schoolwork. Surveys assessed the growth mindset climates in math classrooms.  The present study will analyze NSLM data to investigate if 9th grade math classroom climates and students? use of a growth mindsets worked together to help students successfully complete advanced math and science courses in the early high school years. The four main objectives of the study include: (1) Coding 8th to 10th grade STEM course-taking patterns among students who participated in the NSLM and describing the extent to which minority groups are under-represented in advanced STEM coursework; (2) Testing whether a 9th grade math class with a strong growth mindset climate predicts higher rates of persistence in 10th grade STEM courses among students from under-represented groups; (3) Identifying the growth-oriented teacher practices that best create a growth mindset climate and increase STEM course persistence; and (4) Testing whether the effect on 10th grade STEM course persistence of a growth mindset intervention given directly to students in 9th grade depends on the 9th grade math classroom climate.

Analyses of NSLM data will present a unique opportunity to study why 9th grade math continues to be a gatekeeper course for many underrepresented students. The study will move beyond research that focused on letter grades (i.e. A, B, etc.) and instead focus on course taking patterns (i.e. taking Algebra II in 10th grade or not). Thus, it will advance knowledge about reducing attrition of underrepresented groups in rigorous math pathways. The combined use of quantitative techniques and an integrative theory will help address the ongoing national goal for diversifying the future STEM workforce. Intersectional analyses?which look at groups that have multiple disadvantages, such as students who are both in a racial minority group and who are learning English?are essential to uncovering a deeper understanding of inequities faced by these groups. To do so, the study will build a database that links student and teacher records to validate novel, efficient, and scalable assessments of math classroom climates and math teacher practices useful for improving instructional climates that narrow achievement gaps in high school trajectories. Last, this study will advance knowledge about scalable, low-cost interventions, and identify classrooms where such interventions are most or least effective.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GSE: Research on Gender in S&E

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of the National Study of Learning Mindsets (NSLM) Wave 2 was to investigate how 9th grade math classroom climates and student mindsets work together to broaden participation in STEM courses during the critical first years of high school. When students hold more of a “growth mindset”— the belief that ability can be developed—they display greater motivation and persistence in the face of difficulty. We have developed a short, online, low-cost, and highly scalable intervention, which is the first of its kind, that can teach students a growth mindset. Almost 80% of students in our sample who completed a college-ready course portfolio enrolled in postsecondary during COVID-19 and remained enrolled throughout COVID-19. In addition, there are striking racial/ethnic inequalities in the students’ college-ready graduation rates. A growth mindset intervention, which takes less than an hour and USD 0.5 per student, has proven to improve students’ readiness for college. This one-time intervention in 9th grade showed benefits that extended until the end of high school. Black, Hispanic, and Indigenous students who participated in the intervention were 3.8–4.1% more likely to graduate with a college-ready course portfolio, which can reduce within-school inequality by 30–50%. The study also noted a 2.4% increase in the likelihood among lower-achieving students. The context is important: We need to cultivate a supportive school culture where teachers create a “growth mindset affording classroom culture,” and schools offer students more opportunities to take rigorous coursework.

As part of our data collection for the NSLM Wave 2, we also collected information on students’ postsecondary enrollment from the National Student Clearinghouse. Our most recent data collection includes information on enrollment through May of 2022. This is three years past our cohort’s expected on-time high school graduation in the spring of 2019.  The latest wave reveals information on students’ postsecondary persistence for the two academic years following the onset of COVID-19.Overall, about 63% of our sample had enrolled in a postsecondary institution by May of 2022 at least once. However, this was a tumultuous time for members of our cohort that entered college the fall after high school graduation, with COVID-19 disrupting their college experience about halfway through the second semester of their first year. Mirroring national trends, we find high rates of students exiting college across this period and that many students who had ever enrolled in a postsecondary institution persisted. About 68% of students who enrolled in college in the fall of 2019, maintained enrollment through both the spring and fall terms of the 2020-2021 academic year, and 63% of fall 2019 enrollees were still enrolled as of May 2022.

However, the percentage of enrolled students differed by race/ethnicity and first-generation status. White students enrolled during COVID-19 and were less likely to drop- or temporarily stop-out, remaining continuously enrolled at higher rates than black and Hispanic students. Similarly, only 19% of first-generation students (those without a college-educated parent) maintained continuous enrollment in postsecondary between fall 2019 and spring 2022, compared with 46% of students with a college-educated parent.

While only three years post-high school, our recent data collection also gives initial glimpses into students’ potential degree attainment. As of Spring 2022, about 4.5% of our sample had earned an Associate or Bachelor’s degree, with the vast majority of degrees earned at the Associate level. However, we also find that the college students' enrollment patterns varied by race/ethnicity.  Amongst those who have ever enrolled in postsecondary education, we find that black, white, and mainly Asian students are more likely to attend four-year colleges and universities.  In contrast, indigenous populations (American Indian/Alaskan Native, Hispanic, and Hawaiian/Pacific Islander) are more likely to attend two-year or fewer colleges. These findings have implications for students’ potential attainment, given the degrees earned from each type of school.

 


Last Modified: 02/16/2023
Modified by: David S Yeager
